column1:
flounder
He lost the next page of his speech and floundered around/about for a few seconds.
Although his business was a success, his marriage was floundering.
Richardson resigned as chairman, leaving the company floundering.
column2:
flounder
to move awkwardly or to be in an awkward or difficult situation:

After a brief interlude working as an architect, he went travelling.
The musical interludes don't really fit in with the rest of the play.
column2:

a short period when a situation or activity is different from what comes before and after it:

column1:

Naval gunfire and ground-based artillery are generally less accurate than many aircraft-borne weapons.
column2:
artillery
very large guns that are moved on wheels or metal tracks, or the part of the army that uses these:

column1:
anarchy
What we are witnessing is the country's slow slide into anarchy.
The country has been in a state of anarchy since the inconclusive election.
If the pay deal isn't settled amicably there'll be anarchy in the factories.
column2:
anarchy
a situation in which there is no organization and control, especially in society, because there is no effective government:

column1:
torso
The airbag will protect the head and torso.
a famous marble torso
column2:
torso
the human body considered without head, arms, or legs, or a statue representing this:

column1:
swivel
She swivelled round to look out of the window.
The ostrich swivelled its head in our direction.
column2:
swivel
to (cause to) turn around a central point in order to face in another direction:

column1:
conjugate
The verb "to be" conjugates irregularly.
column2:
conjugate
If a verb conjugates, it has different forms that show different tenses, the number of people it refers to, etc., and if you conjugate a verb, you list its different forms:

column1:
grope
She groped for her glasses on the bedside table.
I had to grope my way up the dark stairs.
column2:
grope
to feel with your hands, especially in order to find or move towards something when you cannot see easily:

peculiarity
You couldn't help but be aware of the peculiarity
Well, we all have our little peculiarities, don't we?

the quality of being strange or unusual, or an unusual characteristic or habit:

auxiliary
auxiliary staff/nurses

directive

criterion

non

Candidates with a qualification in chemistry have exemption from this course.
Organizations may qualify for exemption from income tax if they operate exclusively as charities.
column2:

hypotenuse

hypotenuse
the longest side of any triangle that has one angle of 90°

column1:
incontestable
There is now incontestable evidence that the killings did take place.
column2:
incontestable
impossible to question because of being obviously true:

column1:
brake
She had no brakes on her bicycle.
The driver suddenly put on his brakes.
informal I slammed on (= quickly used) the brakes, but it was too late.
All our new models have anti-lock brakes.

brake

column1: analogue

analogue
An analogue recording is one that is made by changing the sound waves into electrical signals of the same type.

admissible
The judge ruled that new evidence was admissible.
column2:
admissible
considered satisfactory and acceptable in a law court:

column1: lever

lever
a bar or handle that moves around a fixed point, so that one end of it can be pushed or pulled in order to control the operation of a machine or move a heavy or stiff object

column1: non

quotient
This is a car with a high head-turning quotient (= a lot of people turn to look at it).
column2:
quotient
a particular degree or amount of something:

column1:
coincide
I timed my holiday to coincide with the children's.
If the heavy rain had coincided with an extreme high tide, serious flooding would have resulted.
column2:
C2
coincide
to happen at or near the same time:

column1:
complement
Strawberries and cream complement each other perfectly.
The music complements her voice perfectly.
column2:
complement
to make something else seem better or more attractive when combining with it:

B2

column1:
disjunction

column2:

column1: negation

negation

column1:
residue
She cut off the best meat and threw away the residue.
The white residue in/on the kettle is a result of minerals in the water.
column2:
residue
the part that is left after the main part has gone or been taken away, or a substance that remains after a chemical process such as evaporation:

column1: non

operand
a number or quantity that has something done to it in a calculation. For example, in 7 + y, 7 and y are the operands.

column1: non

to show information in the form of a table (= an arrangement of facts and numbers in rows or blocks)

column2:
